docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Wagner approved yesterday a program under which the services of the five New York chapters of the American Red Cross would be used to supplement the work of city agencies in meeting peace-time emergencies and disasters.

headline.main: Red Cross Relief in 619 Disasters Sets Record Over Two-Year Span

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The "Spring offensive" staged by nature in the United States this year has been "the most devastating combination of natural disasters" encountered by the American Red Cross in its sixty-one years of relief work and has cost ...
docs.abstract: N H Davis on U S 1942 Spring disaster relief work

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The "Spring offensive" staged by nature in the United States this year has been "the most devastating combination of natural disasters" encountered by the American Red Cross in its sixty-one years of relief work and has cost that organization more than $1,000,000 for relief and rehabilitation, Chairman Norman H. Davis stated today.

headline.main: Spring Toll of Nature's Disasters Worst in 61 Years of Red Cross; Sixteen Tornadoes Killed 249 and Injured 2,273 -- Cost of Relief Was Over Million, Norman Davis Says in Summary

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   To T. S. Eliot, April was the cruelest month, but when it comes to the anniversary of natural disasters, I would choose October....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To T. S. Eliot, April was the cruelest month, but when it comes to the anniversary of natural disasters, I would choose October.

headline.main: Every Faith Takes Its Own Path to the Sacred; 'The Sublime Spectacle'

docs.snippet: President Nixon today vetoed amendments to the Small Business Act, arguing that their disaster relief sections were likely to cost the Federal Government $800-million more a year and create "an administrative nightmare."...
docs.abstract: Pres Nixon vetoes on Sept 22 amendments to Small Business Act, arguing that their disaster relief sections are likely to cost Fed Govt $800-million more per yr and create 'administrative nightmare'; says bill would provide federally subsidized loans and grants to all disaster victims 'regardless of econ need'; asserts that he continues to hope that Cong will act in '73 on 'much-needed reforms' of disaster assistance program; emphasizes that present disaster aid programs would continue and would not be affected by veto; measure would have increased lending powers of Small Business Adm as well as making changes in disaster loan provisions; Nixon notes that earlier in '73 he proposed fundamental reorgn of disaster aid programs, noting that Govt has responsibility to help disaster victims who cannot help themselves but not those who have their 'own resources'; cites examples
docs.lead_paragraph: President Nixon today vetoed amendments to the Small Business Act, arguing that their disaster relief sections were likely to cost the Federal Government $800-million more a year and create "an administrative nightmare."

headline.main: NIXON VETOES BILL ON DISASTER AID;  As a Crutch'

docs.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, Aug. 21 -- Scientists from the diverse lands encircling the vast basin of the Pacific Ocean assembled here today to discuss the many problems that bind them together -- earthquakes, typhoons and tidal waves.
